results.description:
As some of you will know, we’re in the process of building a citizen science kit in collaboration with the European Space Agency. The kit measures relevant plant and environmental data (and engages citizens in this process) which is then used to create ‘plant models’ for a whole variety of plants.

This informal meetup at BlueCity is our fourth meetup, and we’re going to start building a core development team and start preparing for the hackathon in March (28-29) that will deliver the first prototype of the kit (running doc with specs and more info here: http://bit.ly/MELiSSA_Kit.

Program includes:

• Introduction Watch Me Grow kit (on space farming, ESA's MELiSSA project, objectives, specifications / criteria, and timeline)

• Working and sketching in teams (product design/hardware, electronics, UX/UI, community development, communication, business)

• Reflection and planning/budgeting development track

• BlueCity Lab opening, exposition, and drinks

Let us know if you want to come here and/or leave a comment below.

If you just want to visit the opening of the BlueCity Lab, please check their Facebook event.

This is a small meetup focused on developing a small core-team for building the kit: it's a possibility that we only select a number of registered applicants for this meetup, but all are welcome on the upcoming Watch Me Grow Hackathon in March (28-29).
results.name: Lab Session #4 / IoFriday - Opening BlueCity Lab + pre-hackathon meetup

results.description:
https://www.haagsemakers.nl/programma/iotuesday/

This meetup is invite-only.

During this meetup we focus on the design requirements, build a first mockup using available parts, and establish the BOM for the next meetup (which is open).
results.name: IoTuesday Session 2017#2: WMG dev team meetup

results.description:
The first public IoTuesday session to build the AstroPlant, formerly known as Watch Me Grow.

During the previous two meetings and for the last couple of weeks we've build a first prototype with several sensors, which send out data tot he cloud. Now it's up to you to use your creativity to build engaging interfaces, improve the design, add new components, and make this a valid instrument to determine the plants that will feed our astronauts in the ISS, future Asgardians, Martians, Belters, Spacers, and other future benevolent space colonists.

The program...

Listen to Arn (Haagse Makers) about the first prototype, Thieme (Border Labs, ESA) about the Space Farm Collective and the AstroPlant citizen science project, and Ronald about building the first Food Computer in the Netherlands.

Then build and collaborate on the hardware design, sensors, and the application.
results.name: IoTuesday 2017#4: Design and Build AstroPlant

results.description:
A follow-up session to continue working on the DIY Space Farm kit as well as make preparations for the hackathon. Although the 'formal' program starts at 7pm, you can come earlier, even in the afternoon, to work with us on the prototype.

Short talks by

• Christel Paille (ESA) will tell a bit about MELiSSA and the science behind plants in space

• Jelmer (GIS Planet) about Mars life

• Ronald Timmermans about building the first Food Computer in the Netherlands

• And possibly more.. 

See you next week!

Thieme, Arn, Daniël

--

PS. Sietse Vis (Farmbot) is unable to come, so his presentation is canceled.
results.name: IoTuesday 2017#5: Design and Build AstroPlant

results.description:
https://letitgrow.org/greenhouse-festival/

we've been asked to present our prototype at the upcoming Let It Grow Greenhouse Festival. Working hard to finish it, but we'll be there. Hope to see you there!
results.name: First demonstration AstroPlant at Let It Grow Greenhouse Festival

results.description:
Updates about the program: check borderlabs.org!

Update! Official registration is open - so navigate to http://bit.ly/AstroPlantH and register to secure your spot on this amazing space-ship.

--

Listen to space explorers, inter-stellar gardeners, and use your hands, brains, and creativity to work on DIY space tech that feeds astronauts! Inspiring speakers, hands-on activities to create your own hydroponics system, space for exploration and creativity, good food and amazing people.

The program (for both days) is under construction, but will include a few interesting talks, networking opportunities, workshops, and some great next generation space food from the resident Master Chef of Blue City's Aloha Bar. 

Looking for IoT geeks, science educators, citizen scientists, UI /UX designers, plant biologists, bio-hackers, scientists and just anyone with an interest in growing plants in space and scientific engagement of the public.

IF YOU FANCY THE IDEA OF FARMING IN SPACE: SIGN UP HERE FOR THIS EVENT: http://bit.ly/AstroPlantH

PS> When we oversubscribe, we'll have to make a selection (to ensure a diverse and skilled crowd).

---

Challenges

- The hydroponics growkit business case

- Creative aesthetics for a growkit

- Understanding how plants talk (data & visualisation)

- Engaging young growers (educational & UX challenge)

- Electrify your plants (sensors and electronics)

- A successful crowdfunding campaign

... your challenge here?

---

Confirmed speakers

• Angelo Vermeulen (ESA, NASA, TU Delft, SEAD)

• Lucie Poulet (ESA)

• Zjef van Acker (Association for Vertical Farming)

• Fatima Pínto (ESA education)

• Chloé Rutzerveld (Food artist, designer, explorer)

• Jonas Martens (Better Future Factory)

• more in the pipeline...
results.how_to_find_us: appr. halfway between the center and edge of our galaxy

results.name: AstroPlant pitch at Le Bourget

results.description:
Please follow this link to register.

With the recent developments in spaceflight the rise of the number of people working and living in space will become exponential in the coming decades. How will those people live and what kind of work will they do? One of key elements is how people will use the resources of the solar system to create small settlements early on and later with larger communities. Hollowed asteroids, planetary and moon surfaces, large space stations, they will all become feasible with the large scale development of space.

During the Border Sessions Lab day, people will work in groups of 6 and they will each design based on the resources in our solar system habitats and working places for groups of people of 100 persons.
The teams will be guided by a number of specialists in their respective fields. Teams will each be assigned a planet, moon, asteroid or space station and will start from there. Experience or specific skills required to attend this lab.

WIth Arno Wielders, Frans Blok, Michel van Pelt, Ostap Rudakevych, Masayuki Sono.

<a href="https://www.bordersessions.org/labs/"></a>
results.name: Living and Working Off Earth Hosted by MARS-ONE

results.description:
Please follow this link to register.

Humanity is facing the disconnection between biological reproduction and the body, facilitated by the emerging technology of the Artificial Womb. Envisioned in bleak science fiction scenarios many times in the past, this technology is about to become a reality in our present. But how will it affect our culture – and how should that new culture be designed? And who should be involved in that process? If birds lay eggs, why shouldn’t humans do that, too?

Future Anthropology
After exploring possible food cultures with the Meat the Future project, Next Nature Network sets out to explore the Artificial Womb and its implications on gender, biological reproduction, relationships and love in the future. During a full-day co-creation session at Border Sessions, we will explore both the dreams and the nightmares of this emerging technology. Participants will collaborate on a series of narratives and craft together a piece of ‘design fiction’.

Pyramid of Technology
The creative process will be guided by the Pyramid of Technology, a new speculative design tool and method developed by Next Nature Network that visualizes how technology becomes nature and what we can learn from that. It helps us to dream, build and live in our next nature – the nature caused by humans.

Next Nature Network
Next Nature Network is the international network for anyone interested to join the debate on our future, in which nature and technology are fusing. For more information on the Artificial Womb project, see this article and this timeline on the website of Next Nature Network. For more information about the Pyramid of Technology, click here.

Outline
— Duration: 10:00-17:00
— 50 participants
— Format: participants will work in small groups to produce narratives around the artifical womb and present these in a multimedial way, using objects and images placed on the Pyramid of Technology
results.name: Ectogenesis, Artificial Womb, Human Egg?

venue.name: The Grey Space in the middle

results.description:
Please follow this link to register.

Waag Society’s Open Wetlab presents three Do It Together Biology workshop sessions: ‘Our secret CRISPR Desires’, ‘Do It Yourself Human Enhancement Clinic’ and ‘Aliens in Green’ with outstanding artists, hackers and designers, thinkers and scientists. You can learn experience and create work in the lab together with the experiments in wet technology, DIY human enhancement and trans species communications.

Our secret CRISPR Desires 10.30 – 12.00
Join us to understand and make CRISPR CAS 9 genetic edits and learn about the promises of this much debated and controversial technology that enables us to genetically change micro organisms, plants, animal, humans. You will also learn about your own moral views hidden desires when it comes to genetic beautification and hereditary art.
With Wieke Betten, Dr. Guenter Seyfried, Roland van Dierendonck, Lotte Pet, Pieter van Boheemen, Lucas Evers

Do It Yourself Human Enhancement Clinic 12.30 – 13.30
If Human Enhancement is a variety of technologies that mostly happen far from us, how can a DIY perspective make us create reciprocity: can we do human enhancement ourselves? Isabel Burr Raty will guide us through common and uncommon, traditional and high tech understanding of how we can decolonise our body with DIY medicine, DIY medical applications, DIY enhancement of our organs and parts.
With Isabel Burr Raty

Aliens in Green: Xenopolitics of Hormones 14.00 – 18.00
Aliens in Green (AiG) is an investigative laboratory and tactical performance group that will introduce you – hands-on – in the lab to the toxic impact of endocrine disruption (of the hormone system) and the dominant understanding of who and what are defined as natural. A urine-hormone extraction experiment will enable you to experience results of hormones in other organisms, while AiG will facilitate a discussion about what it means to be alien in the light of (bio-chemical) xeno-forces at play, such as omnipresent plastics in every crack of our ecology.
With Mary Maggic, Spela Petric, Ewen Chardonnet, Julien Bellanger

Open Wetlab at Border Sessions is part of the Do It Yourself Human Enhancement program of Waag Society, Athena Institute – Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, The Arts & Genomics Centre – Leiden University, supported by NWO Kiem and Stimuleringsfonds.
results.name: Open Wetlab hosted by Waag Society’s DIY Human Enhancement Program

results.description: All Border Sessions speakers are invited to join this informal meetup to get to each other. Meet the speakers from abroad, local heroes, and of course the inspiring Border Labs Award finalists.
results.name: Border Sessions Speakers' Drinks

results.description:
Please follow this link to register.

Despite the growing ubiquity of legalized marijuana across countries like the US, this boom hasn’t yet translated into serious innovation. With a significant audience growth opportunity at hand, designers are poised to reinvigorate cannabis’ role, with a vision for more purposeful and enriching experiences. In this ideation session and interactive workshop, we’ll explore the role that enabling technology can play in creating more personalized cannabis offerings. Framed by provocations around cannabis, common user problems, and personalization insights, each group will envision concepts that extend cannabis offerings beyond traditional contexts, into memorable and meaningful experiences that add value to users’ lives.

Participant profile
Diverse group of people representing:
– designers, strategists, product managers, user experience architects, technologists, etc.
– a wide spread of nationalities
– different experience levels (junior/beginner to senior/advanced)
– mix of male/female
– mix of industry expertise

With Nicole Baccus

For this workshop you need to register up front.
results.name: Beyond the Plant: Cannabis 2.0

results.description:
Please follow this link to register.

This workshop gives an essential introduction on how to successfully create practical robotics and mechatronics. It is based on the author’s 33 years of experience of robotics development in Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., JAMSTEC, and Nagasaki University, and contains many examples of real-world robots from new underwater vehicles, ships, robotic fish and unmanned aviation robotics, to space robotics, and medical robotics. You’ll learn how to undertake your personal mission to create your own unmanned robot and imagine how future robotics in society look like.

With Ikuo Yamamoto.'

For this workshop you need to register up front.
results.name: How to Build Your Advanced Robotics for Marine

results.description:
Please follow this link to register.

Self-driving vehicles are here—and cars and trucks are just the beginning. Autonomous vehicles (AVs) will be in our homes, the skies, beneath the earth, in the seas, and in space. And like every major technology, they’ll be used for good and for bad. This workshop grounds you in the state of affairs and in the basic concepts that make AVs work. Together, we’ll explore new ideas for concepts and products in an AV-ified world — for your organizations’s good, or perhaps… more evil purposes. This workshop is aimed at anyone interested in the possibilities and doesn’t require any technical background. It is limited to 25 participants.

With Tim van Deursen and Anton Vanhoucke

For this workshop you need to register up front.

<a href="https://www.bordersessions.org/session/autonomous-vehicles-good-evil/#signup"></a>
results.name: Autonomous Vehicles for Good and Evil

results.description:
Please follow this link to register.

In the field of wearable technology, or so-called 'e-textiles', the relationship between body, technology and environment takes center stage. How can technology help us to connect to our bodies and maximize our senses? During this workshop you will experience in a more intuitive way what e-textile or wearable technology could mean for you. In a playful way, through some movement exercises, we will explore your senses. We will experiment with physical contact to things and others around us, as participants will discover and explore an added layer of communication. Lastly, with a prepared suit embedded with electronics, the participants will interpret the sensation of movements and their connections with others by way of sound.

With Anja Hertenberger

For this workshop you need to register up front.
results.name: TechSense
